info.game_comments:
2003 Teen Tournament final game 2.
(Jimmy: Fasten your seatbelts, driver's ed. clues coming up next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: It's what the "C" stands for in UNICEF, a United Nations international emergency fund

(2, 1).clue: Your KJPY T-shirt gets you half off to see "My Big Fat Greek Wedding", featuring Joey Fatone of this band

(3, 1).clue: Amazon.com allows you to add this "Fudge" author's "Forever" to your "Wedding Registry" list

(4, 1).clue: Florida's governor John Ellis Bush goes by this 3-letter nickname

(5, 1).clue: This man took the title first consul after a coup d'etat in Paris in 1799

(6, 1).clue: 2-letter word that precedes "mine", "good" & "true" on the hearts

(1, 2).clue: It's the U.S. city where you'll find the U.N.'s headquarters

(2, 2).clue: KJPY is sponsoring an in-store appearance by this young lady & we know you'd "Walk a Thousand Miles" to be there

(3, 2).clue: "Troy" by Adele Geras is a young adult novel reworking of this Homer epic

(4, 2).clue: She's the second-generation rocker seen here

(5, 2).clue: The last president of the Soviet Union, he was nearly overthrown in a 1991 coup attempted by his Communist rivals

(6, 2).clue: In 2001 a colon & right parenthesis were put together to create this design on a heart

(1, 3).clue: The U.S. & Great Britain are 2 of the 5 permanent members of this important U.N. group

(2, 3).clue: Caller number 99, you're going to Manhattan to see Dave Matthews at this 7th Avenue & 31st Street arena

(3, 3).clue: There's now a series of books based on this WB series about Lorelai & Rory

(4, 3).clue: Karrie Webb has been called one of the greatest players of this sport, male or female

(5, 3).clue: A coup led by Colonel George Papadopoulos overthrew this country's government in 1967

(6, 3).clue: The pink hearts are cherry flavored, the green, lemon, & the yellow, this

(1, 4).clue: Later U.S. president, in 1971 he was appointed the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations

(2, 4).clue: In the next hour we'll chill out with this band whose hits include "Yellow"

(3, 4).clue: This Meg Cabot book is the first in her series about royal-in-training Mia Thermopolis

(4, 4).clue: He's the popular actor who's not quite seen, but is heard here

(5, 4).clue: Count Grigory Orlov led the palace coup that placed this "Great" empress on the Russian throne in 1762

(6, 4).clue: In the 2001 mix there was the name of this goddess or planet

(1, 5).clue: The father of this U.N. secretary-general was the chairman of the Nobel Prize Foundation

(2, 5).clue: We've got a listener poll -- is this "Fell in Love with a Girl" duo brother or sister, or exes

(3, 5).clue: "They murdered him" begins this Robert Cormier novel

(4, 5).clue: In 1970 this future actor showed some muscle & won the titles Mr. World, Mr. Universe & Mr. Olympia

(5, 5).clue: The 1st commoner to rule England, he became lord protector following the overthrow of King Charles I

(6, 5).clue: Originally called Motto Hearts, the fact they're now called this will give you something to talk about

(1, 1).clue: More than 99.9% of an atom's mass is contained within this

(2, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports)  Just in case you're ever pulled over, you should have with you proof of insurance & these 2 documents

(3, 1).clue: At one point, this largest island in the world is only about 10 miles from Canada

(4, 1).clue: Let's put on this show: I'll play Captain Hook, you'll be Wendy & your creepy little cousins can be the Lost Boys

(5, 1).clue: In the 1960s, many Barbie doll fashions, & even Barbie's bouffant hairdo, were inspired by this First Lady

(1, 2).clue: It's defined as the time required for 50% of the atoms of a radioactive substance to decay into another substance

(2, 2).clue: If, God forbid, the gas pedal sticks on you, quickly shift into this

(3, 2).clue: Nippon is the native name for this country

(4, 2).clue: Mom won't let me be a real pickpocket, but I can play one in this Dickens musical; you can be Mr. Bumble

(5, 2).clue: At her royal wedding in 1999, Sophie Rhys-Jones wore pearl earrings designed by this prince, her bridegroom

(1, 3).clue: This elementary building block of matter comes in 6 types: down, up, bottom, top, strange & charm

(3, 3).clue: The Persian Gulf is an arm of the Arabian Sea, which is part of this ocean

(4, 3).clue: Let's pad your brother so he can play Sancho Panza in this 1965 show -- & that cute babysitter can play Aldonza

(5, 3).clue: Appropriately, this name for a loose, sailor-style blouse is derived from the word "midshipman"

(1, 4).clue: This particle has the same mass as an electron but with a positive charge equal to the electron's negative charge

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports)  When you pull out, check your mirrors & look over your shoulder at the area called this

(3, 4).clue: In 1976 Manila replaced Quezon City as the official capital of this country

(4, 4).clue: Hey, "Don't Cry for Me"!  I won't get the lead in this musical, but I'll be great as Juan Peron

(5, 4).clue: These 2 Hepburns made People magazine's 2000 list of the Best Dressed People of All Time

(1, 5).clue: This isotope of hydrogen is sometimes symbolized H-3

(2, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports)  A good steering wheel position is "9 & 3 o'clock" for cars equipped with these; "10 & 2" is standard for cars without them

(3, 5).clue: Belize & parts of Mexico & Guatemala are located on this peninsula

(4, 5).clue: I insist on a flea collar (& lots of Whiskas in my dressing room) when I play Rumpleteazer in this musical

(5, 5).clue: This rakish lord of poetry, born in 1788, wore romantic open-neck shirts still popular with poets today

(0, 0).clue: James Fenimore Cooper based the character of Natty Bumppo on this man who was born in 1734
